title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.19 | 21-01-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 19th verse of the 16th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the verse that will be discussed.

segments.key_quote: Dharma in the form of a bull asked madam addressing the cow. Are you not hale and hearty? Why are you covered with the shadow of grief?
segments.summary: The speaker presents the translation of Srimad Bhagavatam 1.16.19, where Dharma, in the form of a bull, inquires about the well-being of Mother Earth, represented as a cow, and notices her grief.

segments.key_quote: You are covered with the shadow of grief... Are you suffering from some internal disease? Or are you thinking of some relative who is away in a distant place?
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the verse, explaining the meaning of each question posed by Dharma, highlighting the cow's distress, potential internal suffering, and possible separation from a loved one.

segments.key_quote: This exactly reflects the condition of people in this present age Kali Yuga... Sadhus means they live for welfare of others... He is unhappy because of others unhappiness.
segments.summary: The speaker connects the verse to the current age of Kali Yuga, explaining how the anxieties and suffering described are prevalent today, and defines the role of a sadhu as someone who is compassionate and concerned about the suffering of others.

segments.key_quote: A devotee of Krishna has no reason to be unhappy on his own account. But he is unhappy looking at the condition of the suffering souls... The people of the world in this age of Kali are always full of anxieties.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to describe the suffering in Kali Yuga, emphasizing that devotees are happy in Krishna consciousness but are pained by the suffering of others, and highlights the anxieties and diseases prevalent in this age.

segments.key_quote: Everyone practically feels the absence of his or her relative who is away from home... The particular symptom of the age of Kali is that no family is now blessed to live together.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the breakdown of the joint family system and the separation of family members due to work and other circumstances in Kali Yuga, contributing to unhappiness and anxiety.

segments.key_quote: That's reflected in the condition of the cow mother earth appeared in the form of a cow so I'll stop here thank you very much Hare Krishna
segments.summary: The speaker concludes the discourse, summarizing that the unhappiness in Kali Yuga is reflected in the condition of Mother Earth, represented as a cow.
